awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Directing molecular assemblies into covalently bonded 2D organic materials
awd_abstract_narration:
Professors Robert Bartynski and Sylvie Rangan of Rutgers University New Brunswick and Professor Elena Galoppini of Rutgers University Newark are supported by the Macromolecular, Supramolecular and Nanochemistry (MSN) Program in the Division of Chemistry of the National Science Foundation to develop new methods for the creation of carbon-based two-dimensional materials on metal surfaces.  Ordered arrays of custom designed molecular building blocks are assembled on single crystal surfaces then subjected to an external stimulus, such as heat, light, or energetic electrons, to link together neighboring molecules creating an extended two-dimensional sheet material.  The topology and functionality of the sheet are controlled by judicious selection and placement of the chemical building blocks prior to exposure to the external stimulus.  The resulting sheets hold the promise of displaying a wide variety of novel properties and phenomena such as new forms of magnetism, conduction of electricity with little or no resistance, and efficient emission or absorption of light.  Success of this research project opens the way to new applications of two-dimensional materials in nano-electronics, sensors, solar cells, light-emitting diodes, and other devices that require processability, tunability, high performance, and properties that cannot be obtained with conventional materials.  During the course of conducting the project, the students involved are broadly trained in a multidisciplinary science research environment and provided a chance to interact with scientists in national laboratories.  Undergraduate students from under-represented minority groups are involved in the project and high school students and teachers are mentored.    

The project generates a "toolbox" for on-surface synthesis of two-dimensional (2D) materials.  Different bonding mechanisms that are relevant to on-surface synthesis are explored and ways to create a hierarchy of surface reactions to direct the formation of intermolecular C-C bonds between molecular units to create new 2D organic systems are developed.  The toolbox involves (a) the development of specially designed molecular precursors with functional groups placed at strategic positions, (b) the use of inter-molecular and/or intra-molecular interactions between functional groups, as well as surface templating effects on textured metals, to control the assembly of the molecular precursors on single crystal surfaces.  A particular emphasis is placed on the formation of C-C bonds by dehydrogenation (elimination of H2), dehalogenation (elimination of X2, X = Br, Cl, I) and dehydrofluorination (elimination of HF) reactions.  The nature of the resulting 2D structures are studied through an integrated combination of surface science techniques, including scanning tunneling microscopy, and the electronic properties are examined through a combination of synchrotron-based electron spectroscopies, direct and inverse photoemission as well as ab-initio theoretical methods

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The NSF Chemistry Division supports a Collaborative Research effort entitled “Collaborative Research: Directing molecular assemblies into covalently bonded 2D organic materials” NSF-CHE 1904648 (Bartynski & Rangan, Physics Department at Rutgers-New Brunswick) and  1904654 (Galoppini, Chemistry Department at Rutgers-Newark). This Project Outcomes Report summarizes the results mainly related to CHE-1904654, the part of the collaborative research that focuses on synthetic design of fluorine-substituted molecular building blocks for on-surface synthesis.

In on-surface synthesis, custom-designed molecular building blocks are deposited on single crystal surfaces (for instance metals or metal oxides), then subjected to an external stimulus, such as heat, light, or energetic electrons, that link together neighboring molecules creating an extended two-dimensional (2D) organic material. The topology and functionality of the sheet are controlled by the type and placement of functional groups on the chemical building blocks prior to exposure to the external stimulus, because these groups determine how the molecules will assemble and bind together on the surface.

Periodic, ordered, 2D materials hold the promise of displaying a wide variety of novel properties and phenomena including new forms of magnetism, conduction of electricity with little or no resistance, and efficient emission or absorption of light.  The objective of this collaboration between a surface physicist (Bartynski), a surface physical chemist (Rangan) at Rutgers-New Brunswick and a synthetic chemist (Galoppini) at Rutgers-Newark, is to address one of the main challenges in this field: the ability to control the assembly of the molecular precursors on single crystal surfaces by exploring novel bonding mechanisms, especially involving fluorine atoms, and developing ways to create a hierarchy of surface reactions.  

During this NSF-sponsored research we have made progress mainly in three areas related to on-surface synthesis:

1) The Newark  team designed and synthesized a novel set of strategically fluorine-functionalized molecular building blocks (Fluorinated Zinc tetraphenyl porphyrins, F-ZnTPP) with careful  number and positioning of the Fluorine groups, from 2  to 8 F, and other methylated or brominated porphyrins ZnTPPs that served as reference compounds. The compounds were designed to probe the effect of substituents position (on the pyrrole units or on the phenyl units of ZnTPP), symmetry of substitution (antipodal vs. fully substituted), and hierarchical reactivity (F- vs. H-) in on-surface synthesis approaches. All compounds were characterized by UV-vis and fluorescence spectroscopies, X-ray crystallography, as well as calculations of the ground state molecular properties.

2) Using electron spectroscopy and scanning probe microscopy, the two teams  determined how the F-ZnTPP self-assembled on the single crystal surfaces of Cu(100) and Ag(100).  Depending on the substituents, molecules self-organize into well-defined atomic arrays with specific orientations with respect to the high symmetry directions of the surface, and we understood that the nature of the underlying metal is an important factor.

3) Finally, using electron spectroscopy, scanning probe microscopy and temperature programmed desorption, the New-Brunswick team determined the reaction pathway for the thermally-induced creation of intermolecular C-C bonding   on the single crystal surfaces of Cu(100) and Ag(100)  leading to 2D ribbon-like structures by elimination of H-F or H-H.

One of the main findings is that elimination of HF is facile and occurs at relatively low temperatures, before the  H-H elimination, leaving no residue on the metal substrate (as opposed to  other halogen groups).   This little explored reaction could become a new valuable tool for on-surface synthesis, opening opportunities for self-assembly, unperturbed by reaction by-products, leading to extended covalently bonded periodic organic structures with significantly enhanced long range order.

In terms of the broader impact, organic 2D materials will be critical for the next generation of organic electronics, and the functionalization of organic semiconducting materials for on-surface materials is an important area of research where synhtetic chemists and physicist can work together, like in this case. This work has  contributed by developing new synthetic strategies to form C-C bonds on surfaces that will eventually  allow tuning the electronic properties of the 2D material, and established new surface characterization methods that will allow an improved understanding of this interface.

In terms of educational impact, this interdisciplinary NSF grant provided opportunities for the graduate and undergraduate students involved to work together, co-author papers, and present their work at a number of national and international  scientific meetings and conferences. The regular student exchanges, the  co-advising of Ph.D. theses, and the interdisciplinary collaboration between  synthetic chemists and physicists  has  broadened the scientific education and professional  training of the students from both campuses. Additionally, both teams  have incorporated research conducted under this grant into educational and instructional activities involving undergraduate and graduate students. At Rutgers-Newark the approaches related to on-surface synthesis, including the research developed during the grant period, was  integrated in a graduate course on organic materials, and the results obtained in our studies are used in real-time as examples and the application of principles discussed in the Surface and Interface Science graduate course taught at Rutgers-New Brunswick.
